turns.therapist_last: I appreciate you sharing that with me, Caleb. Can you tell me more about what specifically feels overwhelming in your PhD project? turns.client_last:
Well, it’s just... I feel like there's this pressure to get everything perfect, you know? Like if I don't find something significant or finish all the details just right, then what’s the point? And then I get this nagging thought that I’m just not cut out for this. I mean, I see other people making strides, and I can't help but think, "Why can't I do that?" 

As for progress, I guess there have been moments where I felt like I was on the right track. But those moments feel so fleeting, and then it’s back to feeling like I’m in this never-ending loop of doubt. It’s hard to explain, really. I just... I don’t want to keep feeling like this. But talking about it just makes me feel more overwhelmed, to be honest.

turns.therapist_last: Caleb, it’s clear that the pressure of perfectionism is really holding you back, making it difficult to even consider taking small steps forward. I’d like to invite you to reflect on your values regarding your PhD work and what you hope to achieve through it. How do these feelings of being stuck align or conflict with those values? It might also be helpful to think about any behaviors or thoughts that could be hindering your progress. What would it mean for you to let go of the need for everything to be perfect in this context? Lastly, I want to support you in articulating any motivations you have for change, emphasizing that you have the autonomy to explore this at your own pace.
turns.client_last:
I get what you're saying about reflecting on my values and what I want to achieve. It’s just that when I think about my PhD work, I really want to contribute something meaningful—something that feels significant in the field. But then there's this constant pressure to make sure everything is perfect, and I start to feel like I’m letting myself down if I don’t meet those high standards. It’s almost like I’ve set this impossible bar for myself, and now I’m stuck trying to reach it.

Letting go of the need for everything to be perfect? I mean, that sounds nice in theory, but in reality, it feels really scary. What if I let something slip and it affects the outcome of my work? It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle of wanting to do well but being paralyzed by the fear of not measuring up.

As for motivations for change, I guess I just want to feel more at ease with my work. I want to enjoy the process instead of being consumed by this constant worry. But every time I think about making a change, I get this nagging doubt that makes me question if I’m even capable of it. I don’t know if I’m ready to dive deeper into this right now. It just feels like a lot, and I worry that talking about it more might just make me feel even more trapped.

turns.selector_rationale: The client is expressing doubts and fears about their ability to manage small steps and the pressure of perfectionism, indicating a need to identify specific automatic thoughts driving these emotions. turns.selector_guidance_steps: 1) Ask the client to recall a specific moment when they felt overwhelmed by perfectionism. 2) Encourage them to articulate the exact thought they had at that moment. 3) Help them capture that thought as a clear, concise statement. 4) Validate their feelings associated with that thought without challenging it yet. 5) Invite them to reflect on how that thought influences their emotions and behaviors regarding their PhD work.

full_conversation.content: Hi Caleb, it’s nice to see you. What’s been on your mind that brings you here today?

I guess I've been thinking about my PhD project a lot. It feels like I should be making more progress, but I don't know... it just seems like I'm stuck. Like, the last bit of work always feels so overwhelming, you know? I mean, I should have finished by now, but here I am, still struggling. It’s just frustrating. I’m not sure what to even say about it.

I appreciate you sharing that with me, Caleb. Can you tell me more about what specifically feels overwhelming in your PhD project? I'm curious to understand the parts that are making you feel stuck. Also, have there been any moments along the way where you felt like you were making progress?

Well, it’s just... I feel like there's this pressure to get everything perfect, you know? Like if I don't find something significant or finish all the details just right, then what’s the point? And then I get this nagging thought that I’m just not cut out for this. I mean, I see other people making strides, and I can't help but think, "Why can't I do that?" 

As for progress, I guess there have been moments where I felt like I was on the right track. But those moments feel so fleeting, and then it’s back to feeling like I’m in this never-ending loop of doubt. It’s hard to explain, really. I just... I don’t want to keep feeling like this. But talking about it just makes me feel more overwhelmed, to be honest.

It sounds like you're really feeling the weight of being stuck and overwhelmed with your PhD project. The pressure to achieve perfection must be incredibly challenging, especially when it feels like every detail matters so much. I can understand how those brief moments of feeling like you're making progress can quickly be overshadowed by doubt and frustration. It's completely normal to experience these feelings, and many others in similar situations face the same struggles. If you're comfortable, I'd like to hear more about how this is affecting you without any pressure to find a solution right now.

I appreciate that you understand, but honestly, it’s just hard to dive deeper into this. I mean, I know I’m not the only one feeling this way, but that doesn’t really help me right now, does it? Sometimes it feels like talking about it just makes it worse. I guess I’m just worried that I’ll get stuck in a cycle of overthinking and never really get anywhere. I don't know... I just feel a bit withdrawn, like I’m stuck in my own head and can’t find a way out. It’s frustrating to think about.

It’s clear that you’re experiencing a lot of frustration and feeling withdrawn as you navigate your PhD project. The pressure to achieve perfection seems to weigh heavily on you, contributing to that sense of being stuck. I can see how those fleeting moments of progress are quickly followed by doubt, making it harder to move forward. I'm curious about how discussing these feelings right now is impacting you. Does it feel like it's helping at all, or does it add to the overwhelm?

I guess it’s a bit of both, honestly. I mean, part of me wants to talk about it because maybe it could help, but then there's this other part that feels like... what’s the point? It just makes me think about all the things that aren’t going right, and I end up feeling even more overwhelmed. I know I should be able to handle this, but here I am, feeling stuck. It’s like I’m caught in this loop where every time I try to express how I feel, it just reinforces that sense of being trapped. I don’t want to keep going around in circles. I don’t know if diving deeper is really going to change anything. It just feels like a lot right now.

I hear you, Caleb, and it sounds like you're caught in a tough cycle where discussing your feelings can feel both necessary and overwhelming at the same time. It’s understandable to feel frustrated when expressing yourself seems to reinforce that sense of being trapped. Can you share more about what specific aspects of your project contribute to that feeling of being overwhelmed? Also, when you think about your progress, what thoughts or emotions come up for you? I’d like to understand more about what you believe might help you feel less stuck in this situation.

I guess when I think about the specific aspects that overwhelm me, it’s mostly the fear of not measuring up. Like, I keep thinking about how every detail has to be perfect, and if I don’t get it right, then what’s the point of even trying? It’s like I’ve built this wall around myself, and every time I approach my project, I just run into it. And then there’s the whole comparison thing—seeing others making progress just makes me spiral. I start to feel like a failure, and it’s hard to shake that feeling. 

As for my progress, when I think about it, I just feel... I don’t know, anxious? Like I should have achieved so much more by now. It’s frustrating because I know I’ve done some good work, but those moments feel overshadowed by this constant nagging doubt. I just keep thinking, “What if I’m not cut out for this?” It’s exhausting, really. I don’t want to keep rehashing it, but I can’t help but feel stuck. I mean, I appreciate you asking, but I really don’t know how to get out of this loop.

It sounds like the fear of not measuring up is really weighing on you, and I can see how that creates a barrier when you approach your project. The comparison to others and the feelings of anxiety about your progress seem to be intensifying that sense of being trapped. If you could think of any small steps that might help you feel a bit less overwhelmed or less stuck, what might those be? Also, I want to make sure you feel comfortable discussing these feelings further—are there any concerns you have about continuing this conversation?

I appreciate you asking about small steps, but honestly, I feel like I'm just treading water right now. It's hard to think about taking any steps when I feel so stuck. I mean, even the idea of breaking things down into smaller tasks feels overwhelming because I worry that I won't be able to do them perfectly. It’s like I have this constant fear that if I don’t get things right, then it’s all for nothing. 

As for discussing my feelings further, I guess I’m just kind of hesitant. I don't want to keep going around in circles, and I’m worried about getting deeper into this feeling of being trapped. I know it’s important to talk about things, but part of me just thinks, “What’s the point?” I don’t want to keep feeling like this, but it’s tough to see a way out. I mean, I know I should be able to handle this, but it just feels like a lot right now.

Caleb, it’s clear that the pressure of perfectionism is really holding you back, making it difficult to even consider taking small steps forward. I’d like to invite you to reflect on your values regarding your PhD work and what you hope to achieve through it. How do these feelings of being stuck align or conflict with those values? It might also be helpful to think about any behaviors or thoughts that could be hindering your progress. What would it mean for you to let go of the need for everything to be perfect in this context? Lastly, I want to support you in articulating any motivations you have for change, emphasizing that you have the autonomy to explore this at your own pace.

I get what you're saying about reflecting on my values and what I want to achieve. It’s just that when I think about my PhD work, I really want to contribute something meaningful—something that feels significant in the field. But then there's this constant pressure to make sure everything is perfect, and I start to feel like I’m letting myself down if I don’t meet those high standards. It’s almost like I’ve set this impossible bar for myself, and now I’m stuck trying to reach it.

Letting go of the need for everything to be perfect? I mean, that sounds nice in theory, but in reality, it feels really scary. What if I let something slip and it affects the outcome of my work? It’s like I’m stuck in this cycle of wanting to do well but being paralyzed by the fear of not measuring up.

As for motivations for change, I guess I just want to feel more at ease with my work. I want to enjoy the process instead of being consumed by this constant worry. But every time I think about making a change, I get this nagging doubt that makes me question if I’m even capable of it. I don’t know if I’m ready to dive deeper into this right now. It just feels like a lot, and I worry that talking about it more might just make me feel even more trapped.

It’s evident that you’re feeling a significant amount of pressure to achieve something meaningful through your PhD work, and the fear of not meeting those high standards is understandably overwhelming. I can appreciate your hesitance to let go of that need for perfection; it’s a tough position to be in when it feels like so much is at stake. It’s okay to feel stuck and unsure about diving deeper into these feelings, as many people experience similar challenges in their academic journeys. If you feel comfortable, I’d like to invite you to share any small thoughts or feelings that come up as you reflect on your situation—there’s no pressure to find solutions right now.

I understand that you're trying to help, and I appreciate that. But honestly, it feels like I’m just in this fog, and every time I try to think about it, I end up feeling even more overwhelmed. I mean, the pressure to achieve something significant is like this heavy weight on my shoulders. The idea of letting go of the need for everything to be perfect is just... daunting. What if I miss something important? I feel like I’d be setting myself up for failure. 

I guess when I think about it, there’s this part of me that wants to enjoy my work, but then I get pulled back into that cycle of worry. I keep thinking about how I should be doing better, and it just makes it hard to see any way out. I don’t really want to dig too deep right now because I’m worried it’ll just lead to more frustration. So, I guess I’m just stuck in this place of wanting to move forward but feeling like I can't, you know? I just feel a bit lost.

It sounds like you're really feeling the weight of that pressure to achieve something significant, and I can understand how daunting the idea of letting go of perfectionism can be. It’s completely normal to feel lost when you're caught in that cycle of worry, especially when you want to enjoy your work but feel pulled back by those thoughts of inadequacy. I want to acknowledge how tough this is for you. If you're open to it, we can take our time exploring these feelings together. You’re not alone in this, and it’s okay to share any small thoughts or feelings that come up as we talk. There’s absolutely no rush to find solutions right now. How does that feel for you?

I mean, I get that it’s important to explore these feelings, but it feels like every time I try to articulate what's going on in my head, I just end up feeling more lost. I just don’t want to keep going around in circles. I think, for now, I’d prefer to maybe focus on some practical steps rather than digging deeper into emotions that just feel overwhelming. I’m not sure how to move forward, but I guess I’m just trying to find a way out of this fog without getting too caught up in it.

I appreciate your honesty, Caleb, and it makes sense that you're feeling hesitant to dive deeper right now. It sounds like focusing on practical steps could be a helpful way to navigate through this fog. Can you share any specific practical steps you might consider to feel less overwhelmed with your PhD work? Also, what small changes do you think could help you feel more at ease as you move forward? Let's explore what feels manageable for you in this moment.

I guess when I think about practical steps, it feels like I should really break things down into smaller tasks, but even that feels daunting. I mean, what if I can't do them perfectly? But, maybe I could try setting aside a specific time each week just to focus on my project, even if it's just an hour or so. That way, it’s not like I’m diving in headfirst, but I’m still making some kind of effort. 

I suppose I could also try to remind myself that it’s okay if things aren’t perfect. Like, maybe I could focus on simply making progress instead of worrying about the end result. I think acknowledging that I’m doing my best, even if it doesn't feel like enough, might help a little. 

But honestly, it just feels like a lot to think about right now. I’m worried that these small changes won’t be enough to pull me out of this fog. I don’t want to feel stuck, but at the same time, I’m not sure if I can do it. So, I guess I’m just trying to figure out what feels right without feeling overwhelmed by it all, you know?

When I think about setting aside time for my project, there's this mix of anxiety and a tiny spark of hope.
